Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigation of Cryptic Dextral Faulting and Implications for Seismic Hazard
Award.AbstractNarration:
Locations of active faults and their slip rates and earthquake recurrence intervals are vital inputs for seismic hazard analysis and earthquake forecasting. Although these data are well defined for at risk faults in the U.S., they are lacking for many large and potentially destructive faults elsewhere. Myanmar is an important location to study because of its role in an active strain-partitioned plate boundary and high potential for damaging earthquakes. Myanmar contains many active faults because it accommodates the northward motion of India's collision with Eurasia via strain partitioning. The Sagaing fault is a 1200-km-long right-lateral strike-slip (dextral) fault that accommodates the lateral component of India's northward collision with Eurasia. However, GPS data indicate that the Sagaing fault strains at a rate of ~18 mm/yr, only half the rate of India's movement. Why the Sagaing fault accommodates only half the dextral motion remains unknown, and the locations and rates of other faults that accommodate lateral deformation are not well constrained. The research will be conducted at the Earth Observatory of Singapore (EOS) under the guidance of Dr. Charles Rubin and Dr. Wang Yu, the foremost expert on the tectonics of Myanmar.

This project integrates geologic (slip rates and recurrence intervals) and geodetic (satellite radar) data to investigate spatial and temporal constraints on the location and magnitude of dextral faulting in Myanmar. Interferometric synthetic aperture radar (InSAR) data processed in time series will be used to investigate interseismic strain. Paleoseismic trenching will be employed to constrain fault slip rates and earthquake recurrence intervals. Initial work will focus on the Meiktila Segment of the Sagaing fault, a ~200-km-long seismic gap situated between two of Myanmar's largest cities. The results will further knowledge of strain partitioning processes, as well as inform seismic hazard analysis for the region.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Locations of active faults and their slip rates and earthquake recurrence intervals are vital inputs for seismic hazard analysis and earthquake forecasting. Although these data are well defined for at risk faults in the U.S., they are lacking for many large and potentially destructive faults elsewhere. This results in large uncertainty in earthquake hazard models in densely populated regions at risk of destructive earthquakes. In southeast Asia, oblique convergence at the India-Burma-Sunda plate boundary results in many faults across the Burma plate that accommodate both strike-slip and dip-slip strain. Half the strike-slip strain between India and Sunda plates is accommodated on the Sagaing fault in Myanmar, but where the remaining strain is accommodated remains only partially constrained. This project used satellite radar data to investigate spatial and temporal constraints on the location and magnitude of strike-slip strain on the Burma plate, in parts of northeast Myanmar and eastern India. Satellite radar data allows the study of remote sites that are not possible to access in person and increases both temporal and spatial resolution of data coverage over campaign GPS stations. The results will further knowledge of where strain is accommodated across the Burma plate, as well as inform seismic hazard analysis for the region.

 

Radar data from two satellites were processed in time series for three regions along active faults in Myanmar and eastern India in order to investigate current slip rates and modes of slip (i.e., earthquakes or creep). Only one region afforded sufficient correlation between scenes to produce a times series analysis. Results from this project indicate that: (1) it is possible to use long wavelength (24 cm) satellite radar data in some humid, densely-vegetated regions, but short wavelength radar data only correlate with very short timespans (12 days) between scenes. Long wavelength data correlate with up to a few months between scenes, but still suffer from lack of correlation as compared to arid, less vegetated regions. (2) Aseismic creep may play a large role in accommodating shallow strike-slip strain on the Burma plate. (3) A large fraction of the remaining strike-slip strain may be accommodated on one major fault, and the rest may be partitioned by small amounts on many faults. These results are preliminary. Further work is ongoing, and the study will be submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.
